title: Welcome and introduction

introducer: Colin de la Higuera, LINA, University of Nantes

segmentation: Good morning, welcome to the 2014 Annual Conference of the Open Courseware Consortium.
I've been attending these conferences since 2007.
And I've never been more excited by the content and how the consortium is a global organization.
Is meeting the challenges.
Of open education in today's world.
I'd like to introduce.
The chair for the 2014 conference.
Colin de la Higuera, who's going to take it from here?
Thank you very much welcome.
I see the same.
Welcome to OC WC 2014 global.

The conference has as a second name open education for a multicultural world and it has been the attempt of a number of people involved in organizing this conference to stick to those lines to try and bring into the conference.
People from all over the world and that is what we have in this moment.
I would like to especially welcome the local people people from Slovenia who have massively responded to the calls.
The calls for papers that calls for participation.
We're very happy to have you here and also have a special mention to your colleagues from Indonesia.
So why Indonesia?
Because under an easier was the organizers of the previous edition and it's nice to see that the fact that OSW C has been moving around.
Then hasn't lasting effect.
Well, we're hoping he's got lost where people then get involved and come and present their own works in for some of rather long and difficult journey to come here to come and present their work.
So that's great.
We're really happy about that, so I said there were people who'd worked in this and I really like to thank without giving any names.
Three categories of people.
The star from OSW C. So CWC has got a number of devoted people over the world here.
Have worked on this.
It's fun working with them because they're all the continents, so when you try and sort of have a common phone call, you're sure that one person is going to have to stay up late or get up early.
And it's been great working with him.
Second one is the people from Jozef Stefan Institute.
They are our hosts and they have done well.
I hope we've all seen a marvelous work in the organization, but not just let's say hello.
Classmates also have the scientific aspects.
The 3rd I'll be.
I'll be speaking about.

A new player in the field, which is called knowledge for all so knowledge for all is A is a foundation which was built by researchers and which aims to bring in research into a fields where we feel that our knowledge has to be distributed more widely.
So it seemed clear that being involved in this conference was for us getting the right message of how research can help the message to get through the message of knowledge.
The message of dissemination of.
Educational resources to get through.
So that's where we've tried to do.
So we tried to do it by by.
Fun by participating Tutu.

Choosing the right format for the conference so the format of the conferences that we're going to have 4 tracks running in parallel, so two of these tracks or traditional tracks are related with what oh CWC systematically are usually is.
One of them is policy's, you know?
How do we do in our respective countries or at European level to pass on these open educational resources?
The second track?
Is about pedagogically impact?
How does this help the students to learn?
How does this help the teachers to teach?
And then there was a third track, which we call research and technology and which was very successful in the sense that we did get a lot of papers for this.
So this is where people who are doing research which might not be directly linked with education.
But here you are thinking one second.
What time do you can be really helpful for these people here?
So they've sent us their papers and we will have some, perhaps even technical talks.
And that's I think it's a good thing.
The 4th track is a dissemination track which is about projects that already exists.

Mainly at European level and that are being yes often funded by by European funds, and for which we thought come and tell everybody what you're doing so that we can see you know how there are the tools of tomorrow being prepared.
So this is a bit what we've tried to do.
You know 4 tracks covering different grounds for tracks means 4 rooms means probably 3 possibilities of frustration, right?
Because you have to choose and you can't go to everything.
So in order for you to be less frustrated, everything is going to be recorded.
We've got cameras everywhere.
I don't know if that sounds good, so we've got cameras filming everything and you should be able to see everything later on.

You should also be able to read the papers because all the papers are online and can be read some of the papers have been developed into long papers which have been accepted in a special edition of the Open Practice Journal, so there also there are things to read after the conference to understand more profound way what is happening in the field.

Another novelty linked with the dissemination of what's happening in the conference is something we're calling the video Journal, which is going to be launched during this conference, so the Visual Aid Journal is like a Journal but in self reading.
The articles you're going to see the videos so certain of the papers have been selected for that, and the same.
After the conference, you'll be able to see again or see new things which which can be linked with that.
So a lot of novelties on all those fronts.
All possibly here want to thank another group of people which are.

All the members of the program Committee who worked hard on the scientific aspects and then others that we should thanks because thanks to their generous support, we are being able to help people to travel or we have been also able to keep the fees low.

So we've had a number of sponsors and out of these sponsors, well it's important that we say a word about the Slovenian Post Office which has been specially generous, let's say in the in in these aspects.
OK, so more and more I could go on for a long time, but I don't want to.
I want to just say words about some other exciting things we are doing which is being present on the web.
So there are a number of links.

There are a number of social media that are being used to disseminate to be able to talk with other conferences which are happening at the same time and also perhaps meaner to come here to just say a quick word about this.
Good morning, my name is Mina.
I'm with the Open Courseware consortium so I have 3 minutes to talk about social media.
OK, so many of you have already been tweeting with the #oh CWC Global.
This has been our official hashtag for years for our annual conference.
For.
For updates on the conference, an other news, please follow us on Twitter at OSW News.
Or you can like us on facebook.com/OSWconsortium.
Now, in addition to our usual hashtag, we have a special hashtag this year now.
On in California right now there is a Hewlett grantee meeting an we're in the lovely city of Ljubljana for the OSW C global.
On the other end.
Now, these two groups are not really separate groups, so it was kind of like an accident that the two events fell in same week.
So in order to facilitate a conversation with our friends in California, we decided to play a Twitter ping pong.
So if you tweet any comments about issues, important issues that were brought up at this conference using the hashtag oyar EXE, which stands for Ovr cross continent.
Then our friends in California will answer us back through Twitter and every day I'll give you a daily digest on the Twitter feeds Ann.
It'll be fun to have the conversation going back and forth.
Anne Leslie if you're not a huge fan of social media, you can just go to our conference website.
There is a menu, first social.
If you go into that menu, this is the screen you get if you click on that red button on top, you get all the aggregated feeds according to who's tweeting or what's being treated.
So I'll leave you at that and I look forward to having more conversations with you through social media.
Thank you.
Thank you Mina.
So we should now start the conference and will store the conference by a special event, so I hope, or perhaps some of you have heard about it.
It's an important item on the agenda.
Opening up Slovenia is being launched and we have a panel here which will be talking about opening up education in general and opening up a Slovenia in particular.
And the first person I would like to welcome to Speak.
Is the Slovenian Minister for education yet in a piccolo?
Please come and talk.
